items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but falling slowly, at our Stonor Estate borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding as the catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to high groundwater levels. The weather forecast is for isolated showers today (14/06/2024) which could be heavy at times. This forecast continues over the weekend and into early next week. From Tuesday onwards, it is expected to be predominantly dry with the chance of scattered showers. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message Friday, 21/06/2024, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the River Coln following rainfall over recent weeks and high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the coming days, especially in the Fairford area. The weather forecast is for isolated showers today (14/06/2024) which could be heavy at times. This forecast continues over the weekend and into early next week. From Tuesday onwards, it is expected to be predominantly dry with the chance of scattered showers. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday, 21/06/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
The risk of groundwater flooding at Kimpton and Lilley Bottom has reduced and the flood alert has now been removed. 

The level at the Lilley Bottom borehole has dropped since its peak in late April and is continuing to fall. Any flooding observed over the winter and spring has been minor and is thought to have now receded. 

As measured and forecast rainfall are now at average levels, and capacity in the soil is increasing due to recent drier weather, there is no risk of groundwater flooding in the next few weeks. 

We will continue to monitor the Lilley Bottom borehole once a week as usual.

Groundwater levels in the Flamstead area are considerably higher than expected for this time of year.

The main area at risk of groundwater flooding is Trowley Bottom Valley around Flamstead.

We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks, although levels are starting to drop.

The most important thing to do to prepare for groundwater flooding is to have a personal flood plan.

We are monitoring the situation closely.

The next scheduled update is Wednesday 26th June 2024.

items.description: River Wye and The Hughenden Stream
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling very slowly, on the Hughenden Stream due to high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible, especially in areas closest to the Hughenden Stream in High Wycombe. The weather forecast is for isolated showers today (14/06/2024) which could be heavy at times. This forecast continues over the weekend and into early next week. From Tuesday onwards, it is expected to be predominantly dry with the chance of scattered showers. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday, 21/06/2024, or before if the situation changes.
